addressleaf.section:
De M
r
Bodley a M
r
le comte d'Essex le mois de novembre
1595

page.lettertext:
fol.229r
May it please yo
r
good L. Being sudainely oppressed, when I made my last
dispatch w
t
a fitt of
t
griefe, w
ch
doth never spare me longe, I could
not stay out the writing of a l
re
to yo
r
L
p
. nor yet now as I would for
e same indisposition. But yet to keepe on the course of doing my duetie
I cannot wholy forbeare, though my matter be but slender, having three
dayes agoe bestowed all my store upon
S
r
Robert Cecill
Onely this is
some what more
t
where the states had resolved to reserve
Taxis
l
re
to indure it at the comming of
e Germaine Peacemakers, they
have since thought it better to send it to the
Empero
r
and
e Princes
of
Germany
and to every one in
ticular of
e appointed Commissi-
oners w
th
special l
re
s from themselves to direct them yf they came
from their purposed Ambassade, or els to drawe them by
t
meanes
to consulte a fresh upon it: w
ch
will require some length of time
t
when of force every one must send unto other, and all unto
e Emperor
and he to them again and assigne some other meetinges w
ch
as they
in their busines are wont to proceed will be hardly dispatched in 5 or 6
monethes they feare shall have gained a very great advantage, for de-
feating alltogether
e deseigne of
e enemie for heere they do consider
t
nowe of late they have stoode in ticklish tearmes and
t
as yet there
is no shewe of any great amendm
t
t
if at this instant a troupe of thes
princes shold chance to come hither for so they may w
th
out a passeporte
not comming from the [Enemy] and coverse among
e people w
th
sugred
suasions all this state in a moment might be tourned upside
downe. Taxis l
re
to
e
K.
doth manifest
e meaning of
e chief of
t
Councell
t
it hath no other drifte but to intrappe and betray and
tyrannise at last. The l
re
in my opinion yf yo
r
L. have not redde it,
is not unworthye so much paines aswell for
e matter as to see how a
Spanyard in a question of state doth runne to live and levell and giveth
every point and circumstance his
fect consideration.
A late resolution by
e Enemies sea men in
Dunkerke,
and els
where is drawne such of o
rs
as they take upon the seas w
ch
they used
heretofore to put unto a ransome, doth very much amase o
r
merchants
and fishers for
t
they doubt they shall be forced to sue for sauvegardes
w
ch
was never done hitherto being pointes of such importance as they
cannot falle in practise, but w
th
very great apparance of a dangerous
sequele. The state herupon is very much trobled, to devise to meete
w
th
all inconveniences. The suspition doth encrease of the
enemies intent to come before Calais by reason of some provisions
w
ch
are made at
S
t
Omer
. and
e opinion is here of sundrie
sons of skill
t
is no great masterie, to cutt of
t
haven.
fol.229v
Sith nothing els is offered I cannot end my l
re
wth a better conclu-
sion then w
th
my last humble suite to be favoured by yo
r
L
p
: in your
speeches to her
Highnes
for my licence to come home: where my presence
is so needefull as if it could be seemely for me, to troble yo
r
L
p
. w
th
such
matters I shold make it appeare in two or three lives,
t
never any
had more reason to crave the assistance of his frendes, for his speedy
retourne.
And thus I take my humble leave, w
th
like request
unto yo
r
L
p
. to im
te unto her Ma
tie
and my
L. T
re
r
e resolution of
e states to write unto
e emperor from the Hage. Novem
b
29 95.
Yo
r
L
ps
. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
